disapproval to the body having jurisdiction if the planning commission disapproves the body having jurisdiction may overrule the planning commission by a vote of not less than twothirds  23  of its entire membership for a township that on the enactment date of this act had a planning commission created under former 1931 pa 285 or for a city or village or by a vote of not less than a majority of its membership for any other township if the planning commission fails to act within 35 days after submission of the proposal to the planning commission the project shall be considered to be approved by the planning commission  capital improvements for the purpose of furthering the desirable future development of the municipality under the master plan the planning commission after adoption of a master plan shall annually prepare coordinated and comprehensive programs of public structures and improvements the commission shall annually prepare such a program for the ensuing six 6 years which programs shall show those public structures and improvements in the general order of their priority which in the commissions judgment will be needed or desirable and can be undertaken within the six 6 year period the programs shall be based upon the requirements of the community for all types of public improvements and to that end each agency or department of the city concerned with such improvements shall upon request furnish the commission with lists plans and estimates of time and cost of those public structures and improvements the commission may recommend to the city commission programs for public structures and improvements and for the financing thereof  coordination a the commission shall have the power to promote public interest in and understanding of the plan and to implementation of the citys development policy and master plan with other city agencies and boards to this end other agencies and boards may submit to the planning commission their projects plans and grant requests for a finding of consistency with the approved development policy and master plan the commissions determinations in the consistency matters shall be submitted to the city commission b the commission shall consult and advise with public officials and agencies public utility companies civic educational professional and other organizations and with citizens with relation to the protecting or carrying out of the plan  staff support the city manager shall appoint the city planner or such other officer as he may determine to act as staff support to the commission such staff support shall provide the commission the data options and analysis needed by the commission to make determinations and recommendations  approval ratification and reconfirmation all official actions adopted  secs 21612168  reserved article iv  purchases short title this article shall be known and may be cited as the purchasing the city of sault ste marie michigan 01 52471 definitions for the purposes of this article the following terms phrases words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein the word shall is always mandatory and not merely directory city purchasing agent or agent is the purchasing agent of the city contractual services shall mean and include all telephone gas water electric light and power service towel and cleaning service  insurance  leases for all grounds buildings office or other space required by the using agencies  and the rental repair or maintenance of equipment machinery and other cityowned personal property the term shall not include professional and other contractual services which by their nature are unique and not subject to competition supplies materials and equipment as used throughout this article shall mean any and all articles or things which shall be furnished to or used by any agency including all printing binding or publication of stationery forms journals and reports using agency means any department agency commission or other unit in the city government or a unit other than the city government making use of the city purchasing department using supplies or procuring contractual services as provided for in this article 02 52471 establishment of office of purchases there is hereby established as prescribed by section 46 of the charter the department of purchases and supplies to be administered by a director of purchases and supplies or purchasing agent under the direction and control of the city manager as provided by the charter 03 52471 city purchasing agent a generally the city purchasing agent shall be the head and have general supervision of the office of the department of purchases and supplies the agent shall perform all duties required of a department head by law and shall have the powers and duties prescribed by this article b scope of purchasing authority the agent shall have the powers and duties as follows 1 purchase or contract to purchase or contract for all supplies and contractual services required by any using agency in accordance with purchasing procedures as prescribed by this article and such rules and regulations as adopted by the purchasing procedural committee for the internal management and operation of the department of purchases and supplies 2 unauthorized purchases except as herein provided it shall be unlawful for any city officer or officers to order the purchase of any supplies or make any contract within the purview of this article other than department of purchases and supplies and any purchase ordered or contract made contrary to the provisions hereof shall not be approved by the city officials and the city shall not be bound thereby c other powers and duties in addition to the purchasing authority conferred above and in addition to any other powers and duties conferred by this article the agent shall 1 minimum expenditure act to procure for the city the highest quality in supplies and contractual services at the least expense to the city 2 encourage competition discourage uniform bidding and endeavor to obtain as full and open competition as possible on all purchases and sales 3 rules and regulations the agent shall be responsible for the establishment and amendment when necessary of all rules and regulations authorized by this article the charter and any other ordinances pertaining to purchasing which have been or may be enacted such rules and regulations shall be established and amended by a purchasing procedural committee which shall be composed of the city manager purchasing agent and finance officer and shall be in the form of a purchasing manual which shall be revised and updated to conform to changing conditions 4 purchasing analysis keep informed of current developments in the field of purchasing prices market conditions and new products and secure for the city the benefits of research done in the field of purchasing by other governmental jurisdictions national technical societies trade associations having national recognition and by private businesses and organizations 5 forms prescribe and maintain such forms as shall be reasonably necessary to the efficient and effective operation of a department of purchases and supplies 6 vendors catalog file prepare adopt and maintain a vendors catalog file or library such catalogs shall be filed as nearly as may be according to materials and shall contain if possible description of materials vendors commodities prices and discounts 7 bulk purchases explore and make use of the possibilities of buying in bulk so as to take full advantage of quantity discounts the cooperative purchasing or purchasing for other governmental agencies or political subdivisions is to be encouraged and explored by the agent 04 52471 capacity of agent a generally the agent shall enforce the written specifications adopted b agents duties it shall be the duty of the agent 1 classification to classify all supplies used by the using agencies 2 standardization to adopt as standards the minimum number of qualities sizes and varieties of supplies consistent with the successful operation of the city government 3 specification to prepare and adopt written specifications of all such standard supplies c consultation with using agencies the agent shall consult with the heads and other officials of the using agencies to determine their precise requirements and shall endeavor to prescribe those standards which meet the needs of the majority of such agencies d nature of specifications all specifications shall be definite and certain as nearly as may be and shall permit of competition  provided however that the provisions of this subsection shall not apply to noncompetitive types or kinds of supplies 05 52471 requisitions and estimates all using agencies shall file with the purchasing agent detailed estimates of their requirements in supplies materials equipment and contractual services in such manner at such time and for such future periods as the agent shall prescribe this shall not prevent any using agency from filing with the purchasing agent at any time duly approved requisitions for supplies equipment or commodities as required 06 52471 encumbrance of funds except in cases of emergency the agent shall not issue any purchase order for delivery on a contract or open market purchase until the finance officer has certified that there are unencumbered funds to the credit of the using agency to defray the amount of such order when the total cost requisitioned exceeds the amount the finance officer has been authorized to approve by the city manager such requisition shall bear the approval of the city manager prior to the issuance of a purchase order 07 52471 competitive bidding required all purchases of and contracts for supplies materials equipment and contractual services and all sales of personal property which has become excess or obsolete and unusable shall except as specifically provided in this article be based wherever possible and feasible on competitive bids 08 52471 formal contract procedure a generally all supplies and contractual services except as otherwise provided in this article and by the charter when the estimated cost thereof shall exceed ten thousand dollars $1000000 shall be purchased by formal written contract from the lowest responsible bidder after due notice inviting proposals b notice inviting bids notice inviting bids shall be published at least once in an official publication of general circulation in the city and surrounding area at least five 5 days preceding the last day set for the receipt of proposals at the discretion of the agent notices may be published in publications of greater area circulation than the local paper 1 scope of notice the newspaper notice required in this subsection shall include a general description of the articles to be purchased or sold shall state where bid blanks and specifications may be secured and the time and place for opening bids 2 bidders list the agent shall also solicit sealed bids from all responsible prospective suppliers who have requested their names to be added to a bidders list which the agent shall maintain by sending them a copy of the notice which will acquaint them with the proposed purchase or sale c bid deposits when deemed necessary by the agent bid deposits or surety in the form of check cash or bond shall be made a part of the specifications unsuccessful bidders shall be entitled to return of surety upon awarding or rejection of bids a successful bidder shall forfeit any surety required by the agent upon failure on his part to enter a contract within a reasonable length of time after the award d bid opening procedure 1 submittal sealed bids shall be submitted sealed to the purchasing agent and shall be identified as bids on the envelope 2 opening bids shall be opened in public at the time and place stated in the public notice 3 tabulation the tabulation of all bids received shall be open to public inspection e bid handling the tabulation of the bids received along with the recommendation of the purchasing agent shall be submitted to the city manager who shall submit such information with a recommendation to the city commission for commission action f award of contract the agent shall have the authority to award contracts under the section 2177 limit and recommended to the city manager the awarding of contracts involving expenditures in excess of the section 2177 limit with the purview of this article g lowest responsible bidder contracts shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder in determining the lowest responsible bidder in addition to price the agent shall consider 1 the ability capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service required  2 the time element  whether or not the bidder can perform the contract or provide the service promptly or within the time specified without delay or interference  3 the quality of performance of previous contracts or services  4 the previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances relating to the contract or service  5 the sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service  6 the ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service for the use of the subject of the contract h award to other than low bidder when the award is not given to the lowest bidder a full and complete statement of the reasons for placing the order elsewhere shall be prepared by the agent and filed with the other papers relating to the transaction i tie bids 1 local vendor if all bids received are for the same total amount or unit price quality and service being equal the contract shall be awarded to the local bidder 2 outside vendors when subsection i1 is not in effect the agent shall award the contract to one of the bidders by publicly drawing lots j performance bonds the agent shall have the authority to require a performance bond before entering a contract in such amount as he shall find reasonably necessary to protect the best interests of the city k prohibition against subdivision no contract or purchase shall be subdivided to avoid the requirements of this section 09 52471   7207 open market procedure a generally all purchases of supplies and contractual services and all sales of personal property which has become obsolete and unusable of less than the estimated value of the section 2177 limit may be made in the open market without newspaper advertisement and without observing the procedure described by section 2177 for the award of formal contracts b minimum number of bids all open market purchases shall whenever possible be based on at least three 3 competitive bids and shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder in accordance with the standards set forth in section 2177g c bid invitations the agent shall solicit bids from interviews with representatives by telephone direct mail or personal delivery to prospective vendors d recording the agent shall keep a record of all open market orders and the bids submitted thereon for a period of six 6 months which records shall be open to public inspection e rejection of bids the agent shall have the authority to reject all bids parts of all bids or all bids for any one or more supplies or contractual services included in the proposed contract when the best interest of the public will be served thereby f source establishment by bid the purchasing agent may establish sources of supply for various commodities supplies or material by means of the procedures as set forth in this section even though the aggregate amount which may be purchased over a period of time may exceed the section 2177 limit limitation for a single purchase 10 52471   7207 emergency purchases in case of actual emergency and with the approval of the agent a department head or duly authorized agent thereof may purchase directly any supplies whose immediate procurement is essential to prevent delays in the work of the using agency which may vitally affect the life and health or convenience of citizens such purchases shall be made in compliance with prescribed rules and regulations as set forth in the purchasing manual provided further that the amount does not exceed the section 2177 for a singlelimit purchase 11 52471   7207 inspection  tests a the agent shall have the authority to inspect or cause to be inspected all deliveries of purchases to determine their conformance with the specifications set forth in the order or contract b the agent shall have the authority to require chemical or physical tests of samples submitted with bids and samples of deliveries which are necessary to determine their quality and conformity with the specifications in the performance of such tests the agent shall have the authority to make use of laboratory facilities of any outside laboratory 12 52471 surplus and obsolete stock a generally all using agencies shall submit to the agent at such times and in such form as he shall prescribe reports of stocks supplies or equipment which are no longer used or which have become obsolete worn out or scrapped b sale the agent shall have the authority to sell all supplies which have become unsuitable for public use or to exchange the same for or trade in the same on new supplies 1 competitive bidding sales of personal property the value of which exceeds the section 2177 limit and all sales of real estate property shall be made to the highest responsible bidder in conformance with section 2177 2 open market procedure sales of personal property the value of which does not exceed the section 2177 limit may be made to the highest responsible bidder in conformance with section 2178 13 52471   7207 cooperative purchasing the agent shall have the authority to join with other units of government in cooperative purchasing plans when the best interest of the city would be served thereby 14 52471 exceptions to competitive bidding competitive bidding shall not be required for the following activities 1 where the product or material contracted for is not competitive in nature and no advantage to the city would result from requiring competitive bidding or the city commission authorizes execution of a contract without competitive bidding as provided by section 121 of the charter  2 the employment of professional services  3 when the department of purchases and supplies shall determine that the public interest will be best served by purchase from or joint purchase with another government unit  4 when the city elects to undertake the work itself as provided by the charter terms and conditions are met 1 the dollar amount of said change order shall not exceed ten 10 per cent of the original bid award on the entire construction project  provided however that in no event shall the change order amount exceed ten thousand dollars $1000000  and 2 such change orders authorized by the city manager shall not exceed the funds budgeted for the particular construction project in question  and 3 no contract or change order shall be subdivided for the purpose of circumventing the ten 10 per cent bid award limitation contained in this section  11981 local bid adjustment and award a this section applies to purchases only b a city or county local bidder is defined as either a bidder who owns land in the city or the county  and upon such land its business is located  and who owned the land continuously for the twelve 12 months prior to the bid  and who is current on all obligations and property taxes owed to the city or the county as the case may be  and has paid in bid  and who is current on all obligations owed to the city or the county as the case may be d any bid made by a local bidder as defined above shall be provided a competitive adjustment to their bid at the time of tabulation if a city local bidder then equal to five 5 percent of the low bid amount not to exceed $1000000 if a county local bidder then equal to three 3 percent of the low bid not to exceed ten thousand dollars $1000000 e the competitive adjustment for purposes of determining the award of the bid shall reduce the local bidders bid artificially as means of determining if the award to the local bidder is in the best interest of the city f lowest responsible bidder defined under subsection 2177g and award to other than low bidder under subsection 2177h shall include the match the actual bid submitted by the nonlocal bidder  51408   10509   51710   101915 secs 21862299  reserved article v  code of ethics and conduct preamble in keeping with the policies declared by the state legislature in enacting codes of ethics for state officials it is recognized that high moral and ethical standards among city officials are equally essential to the conduct of local and state government  that a code of ethics for the guidance of city officials is necessary in order to prevent conflicts of interest in public office improve standards of public service and promote and strengthen the faith and confidence of the people of the city in their governing body the ethics and conduct board will initially receive and process complaints or allegations of violations of the city code of ethics and conduct  9407 secs 23012309  reserved ethics and conduct definitions no city officer shall violate the standards of conduct or procedural parameters as used in this article a city officer means an elected commissioner mayor employee of the city or the members of the several boards and commissions created by or under the authority of the sault ste marie city charter or applicable state law b unethical conduct means a violation of the standards of conduct contained in this article c incompatible offices means the standards of conduct prescribed by 1978 pa 566 d conflict of interestkinship means the contracting with an entity that is either wholly owned or that is controlled by and controlling interest by a person who is a member of the city officers family as defined in city charter subsection 514a e person means any business individual club other organization or group of individuals f procurement means the buying purchasing renting leasing or otherwise acquiring of any supplies services or construction it also includes all functions that pertain to the obtaining of any supply service or construction including description of requirement selection and solicitation of sources preparation and award of contract and all phases of contract administration g gratuity means an item of value in excess of twentyfive dollars $2500 such as a payment loan subscription advance deposit of money service alcoholic beverages or anything else of more than a twentyfivedollar $2500 value present or promised unless consideration of substantially equal or greater value is received h confidential information means any information which is available to a city officer only because of the city officers status with the city of sault ste marie and is not a matter of public knowledge or available to the public on request i contract means all types of agreements regardless of what they may be called for the sale of city real or personal property procurement of supplies services or construction j contractor means any person having a contract with the city or an agency thereof k services means the furnishing of labor time or effort by a contractor not involving the delivery of a specific end product other than reports this term shall not include employment agreements or collectivebargaining agreements l direct participation means substantial involvement approval disapproval or preparation of any part of a purchase request for the purposes of influencing the content of any specification or procurement standard m nonemployee means any person not an officer or employee of the city who is involved directly or indirectly including third party in the procurement process with the city n conflict of interestemploymentfinancial means a personal interest of such substance as to induce action on his or her part to promote the governmental decision or contract for his or her own personal benefit o governmental decision means a determination action vote or disposition upon a motion proposal recommendation resolution ordinance or measure on which a vote by a defined city officer of the public body is required and by which the public body formulates or effectuates public policy p minor violation means a violation of this article where the acts or omissions of the violator only 1 meet the prohibitions of conduct contained in this article in a limited fashion  and 2 where there is only indirect benefit to the violator q major violation means a violation of this article where the acts or omissions of the violator 1 meet the expressed prohibitions of conduct contained in this article in a direct fashion  and 2 where there is direct benefit to the violator  9407 secs 23112314  reserved standards of conduct a disclosure of confidential information and city officer status activities within one year it shall be unethical for a city officer to use or divulge to any person confidential information acquired in the course of city service in advance of the time prescribed for its authorized release to the public no city officer shall except as required in the performance of his duties or in the course of any conduct reasonably believed to be in the performance of his duties disclose confidential information gained by reason of his or her official position nor shall he otherwise use the information for his personal interest confidential information shall include 1 personnel information applications or any files maintained for city officers  2 information required of any taxpayer or city license holder in connection with the assessment or collection of any tax or license fee if the disclosure of the information to other persons would violate the taxpayer or licensees right to privacy  3 specific intelligence information and specific investigative files compiled by investigative law enforcement and penology agencies and those state agencies vested with the responsibility to discipline members of any profession the nondisclosure of which is essential to effective law enforcement or for the protection of any persons right to privacy 4 information revealing the identity of persons who file complaints with investigative law enforcement or other government agencies except as the public disclosure laws may authorize  5 test questions scoring keys and other examination data used to administer license employment or examination license or employment examinations  6 preliminary drafts notes recommendations and intraagency memorandums in which opinions are expressed or policies formulated or recommended except that a specific record shall not be exempt when publicly cited by an agency in connection with any agency action  7 records which are relevant to a controversy to which the city or any of its officers employees or agents is a party and would not be available to another party under the rules of pretrial discovery for causes pending in the courts  8 any other information as is declared confidential by other specific statutes  9 the confidential areas herein above listed shall be inapplicable to the extent that information the disclosure of which would violate personal privacy or vital governmental interest can be deleted from the specific records sought to further the goal of maintaining confidences and preventing confidences from being used for personal gain a person who was a city officer shall not within one 1 year of his or her leaving the city office be an employee of any entity who seeks a contract with the city without obtaining approval of the city commission b use of city property it shall be unethical for a city officer to use personnel resources equipment property and funds under the officers official care and control for personal gain or benefit unless used judiciously and solely in accordance with prescribed constitutional statutory and regulatory procedures c gifts or loans it shall be unethical for a city officer to solicit or accept a gift or loan of money goods services or other thing of value for the benefit of a person or organization other than the city which tends to influence the manner in which the city officer or another city officer performs official duties d personal profit it shall be unethical for a city officer to engage in a business transaction in which the city officer may profit from his or her official position or authority or benefit financially from confidential information which the city officer has obtained or may obtain by reason of that position or authority e gratuities it shall be unethical for a city officer to accept a gratuity or an offer of employment in connection with a decision approval disapproval recommendation or preparation of any part of a program requirement or a purchase request influencing the content of any specification or procurement standard rendering of advice investigation auditing or in any other advisory capacity in any proceeding or application request for ruling determination claim or controversy or other particular matter pertaining to any program requirement or a contract or subcontract or to any solicitation or proposal therefore f kickbacks it shall be unethical for a city officer to be directly or indirectly involved in any payment gratuity or offer of employment to be made by or on behalf of a subcontractor under a contract to the prime contractor or higher tier subcontractor or any person associated therewith as an inducement for the award of a subcontract or order g incompatible employment it shall be unethical for any city officer to violate the standards of conduct prescribed in 1978 pa 566 h incompatible offices it shall be unethical for any city officer to violate the standards of conduct prescribed in 1978 pa 566 i incompatible kinship it shall be unethical for any city officer to violate the standards of conduct prescribed in subsection 2310d described herein j contract fixing it shall be unethical for a city officer to participate in the negotiation or execution of contracts making of loans granting of subsidies fixing of rates issuance of permits or certificates or other regulation or supervision relating to a business entity in which the city officer has a financial or unethical interest k unethical hiring it shall be unethical for a city officer to be hired or to for a city officer to violate the standards of conduct prescribed in subsection 2310n described herein m participation in decision making before debate or a motion proposal recommendation or commission members commission members will hereafter conduct themselves according to the following rules of conduct as they pertain to work for and on behalf of the city 1 a commission member shall maintain decorum and set an example for conduct when the commission member represents the city constituents principals or themselves personally commission members shall conduct themselves so as not to bring disgrace or embarrassment upon the city conduct such as name calling yelling screaming use of fighting words threatening retribution or similar activity shall be prohibited 2 a commission member shall always represent that opinions stated are the members own and do not necessarily represent those of the commission unless the commission has voted and passed an ordinance resolution or motion that so states the expressed policy 3 if a commission member writes to a citizen the member may use city stationery however the form and language must clearly state that opinions are those of the writer unless the commission has taken some official action the commission member shall sign hisher name as mayor mayor pro tem or commission member as applicable 4 a commission member must obtain approval of the commission by motion to represent the city to any organization 5 a commission member must obtain approval of the commission by motion to attend any activity for which the city will pay for travel and other expenses 6 a commission member shall not divulge the discussions held in closed session until or unless the commission itself has made the discussions public 7 a commission member shall not make false statements on which the commission city staff or other agencies rely to establish policy or make important decisions a commission member violates this rule if he or she knows it is untrue or if he or she has knowledge that would lead a reasonable person of ordinary prudence to conclude that the statement is untrue 8 a commission member shall not interfere with the city three 3 people who are not city officers and who are appointed by the city commission under this section the city clerk shall act as secretary for the board each members term shall be for three 3 years members of the board shall be initially appointed for the terms of one 1 two 2 and three 3 years respectively annually thereafter one 1 member shall be appointed for a full threeyear term the rules of procedure for violations and penalties are as follows a any officer who believes that another officer has violated this article shall submit a written statement of the purported violation to the secretary of the ethics and conduct board b the board shall review the violation to determine whether adequate reasons exist to bring formal charges c the board shall come to one of the following conclusions 1 there is insufficient evidence to conclude that any particular violation has occurred in this case the board shall keep any records confidential 2 the board concludes it is more likely than not that there has been a violation in which case the board may call for full review by the city commission or the city manager if the complaint involves a city employee under the managers control under the charter d if the board concludes there may have been a violation the city commission or manager shall classify the possible violation as major or minor if the city commission or manager determines that a minor violation has occurred it shall administer a censure the violator may demand a public hearing for minor violations a major violation shall result in a public hearing by the city commission or manager if before the city commission it shall select one of its members to present its findings at the hearing the accused violator shall neither conduct the meeting during the hearing nor shall the member present the findings of the city commission the city commission or manager shall give the accused violator adequate time to prepare a case and to present the case at the public hearing both the city commission or manager and accused member shall present their own cases but they may be accompanied by counsel during the proceedings the city commission presenter or manager and the accused may present witnesses who shall present their evidence under oath after hearing the evidence the city commission or manager shall determine whether the purported violation was major minor or whether there is insufficient evidence to determine that a violation occurred if the city commission or manager determines that a violation occurred they shall also establish a penalty commensurate with the violation as follows 1 oral or written warnings or reprimands  2 suspension of duties for specified periods of time  or 3 termination of duties the city commission may remove the violator from the positions of commissioner mayor or mayor pro tem if applicable as part of the penalty if they deem it appropriate  9407 secs 23412344  reserved recovery of value transferred or received in breach of ethical standards a general provisions the value of anything transferred or received in breach of the ethical standards of this article by persons affected by this article may be recovered by and on behalf of the city for the sole benefit of the city b recovery of kickbacks by the city upon a showing that a subcontractor made a kickback to a person affected by this article to a prime contractor or a higher tier subcontractor in connection with the award of a subcontract or order thereunder it shall be conclusively presumed that the amount thereof was included in the price of the subcontract or order and ultimately borne by the city and will be recoverable hereunder from the recipient in addition that amount may also be recovered from the subcontractor making such kickbacks recovery from one offending party shall not preclude recovery from other offending parties  9407 secs 23462349  reserved severability savings repealer sanctions a if any section subsection of ten 10 days the animal shall be examined immediately after it has bitten anyone and again at the end of such tenday period if a veterinarian is convinced that the animal is free of rabies the follows 1 to identify and enumerate certain animals which by their nature are sufficiently dangerous undesirable or unsuitable for incorporation into the residential agricultural or commercial life of this community 2 to impose prohibitory measures to discourage and ban the possession and maintenance of animals considered as exotic and not easily domesticated 3 to establish guidelines and procedures to be utilized by animal control personnel in implementing this article 4 to provide for penalties and sanctions for violations hereof  10295 legislative classification and findings a with the increasing urbanization and population density of the city the residents of the city must be protected from the attack and threat of injury or disease from certain exotic animals possessed or maintained as domestic animals b this article is enacted following the passage of act 381 of the public acts of 1988 mcl 75049 msa  by the state legislature which provides for substantial penalties to be imposed against persons who promote the possession or use of dogs bred for fighting or baiting c this article is enacted following the passage of act 426 of the public acts of 1988 mcl  et seq msa 21 et seq by the michigan legislature which provides for additional penalties and procedures for the protection against dangerous animals  10295 secs 778 779  reserved minimum requirements for keeping dangerous animal a at all time when such animal is outside of any enclosed structure fenced yard or fenced running area the animal shall 1 be under the control of a person over the age of eighteen 18 years 2 be held securely by a leash of adequate strength to restrain the animal 3 have a muzzle over its jaws sufficient to prevent the animal from inflicting any bite upon another person or animal c all properties where the animal is kept harbored or possessed shall at all times be insured with public liability insurance for bodily injury and property damage by such animal in an amount no less than five hundred thousand dollars $50000000 coverage proof of such insurance shall be submitted to the city clerk upon demand d pens or structures utilized for harboring or keeping such animal if a dog outside of a habitable structure shall be a minimum of five 5 feet wide ten 10 feet long five 5 feet in height above grade the pen must not share common fencing with the area or perimeter fence of the property the pen must have secure sides and a secure top attached to all sides all to be constructed with at least 12gauge heavier if necessary to contain animal chain link fencing with necessary steel supporting posts the sides must be either buried two 2 feet into the ground wired or otherwise securely attached to a continuous floor of chain link fencing material or adequately secured to a concrete pad the pen must be securely locked with a key or combination lock when the dog is within the pen all pens erected to satisfy this section must also comply with all zoning and building regulations of the city all pens must be kept clean and in a sanitary condition  10295 prohibited exotic rare or dangerous animals a it shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any person destruction or removal under this article if so the court shall order the destruction of the animal at the expense of the owner or in the alternative at the courts discretion order the animal removed 81348189  reserved article viii  registry of owners and premises definitions certain words in this article are defined for the purposes thereof as follows words used in the present tense include the future  words in the masculine gender include the feminine and neuter  the singular number includes the plural and the plural the singular 1 dwelling a dwelling is any house building structure shelter or portion thereof except railroad cars on tracks or rightsofway which is occupied in whole or in part as the home residence living or sleeping place of one 1 or more human beings either permanently or transiently a house trailer or other vehicle when occupied or used as a dwelling shall be subject to all the provisions of this act except that house trailers or other vehicles duly licensed as vehicles may be occupied or used as a dwelling without being otherwise subject to the provisions of this act for dwellings when located in a park or place designated or licensed for the purpose by the city  provided that such parking sites are equipped with adequate sanitary facilities 2 classes of multiple dwellings all multiple dwellings are dwellings and for the purpose of this act are divided into 3 classes being class a class b and class c class a multiple dwellings of class a are dwellings which are occupied more or less permanently for residence purposes and in which the rooms are occupied singularly in apartments suites or groups  in which each room or combination of rooms is so arranged and designed as to provide for cooking accommodations toilet and kitchen sink accommodations within the separate units this class includes tenement houses flats apartment houses bachelor apartments studio apartments duplex apartments kitchenette apartments and all other dwellings similarly occupied whether specifically enumerated herein or not class b multiple dwellings of class b are dwellings which are occupied as a rule transiently as the temporary abiding place of individuals who are lodged with or without meals and in which as a rule the rooms are occupied singularly and without any attempt to provide therein or therewith cooking or kitchen accommodations for the individual occupants this class includes hotels motels clubhouses hospitals jails and all other dwellings similarly occupied whether specifically enumerated herein or not class c multiple dwellings of class c are dwellings which are occupied more or less permanently for residence purposes and in which the rooms are occupied singularly in apartments suites or groups and where the dwelling is designed to provide for cooking accommodations toilet and kitchen sink accommodations outside of the separate rooms or units this class includes fraternities sororities apartment hotels nursing facilities and other communal residence houses and all other dwellings similarly occupied whether specifically enumerated herein or not 3 rooming house a rooming house is any owneroccupied singlefamily dwelling occupied as the owners home and occupied in such a manner that certain rooms in excess of those used by the members of the owners immediate family are leased or rented to persons outside of the family with or without any attempt to provide therein or therewith cooking or kitchen accommodations for individuals leasing or renting rooms 4 bed and breakfast houses a bed and breakfast is a singlefamily residential structure that meets all of the following criteria a has ten 10 or fewer sleeping rooms including sleeping rooms occupied by the innkeeper one 1 or more of which are available for rent to transient tenants b serves meals at no extra cost to its transient tenants 5 agent agent means a person who has charge care control or management of a dwelling 6 owner owner means a person who has a legal or equitable interest in a dwelling regardless of whether the person has possession of the dwelling owner includes an executor administrator trustee or guardian of the estate of an owner of a dwelling 7 residential rental property residential rental property means any dwelling or multiple dwelling of class a or class c the right to possession of which has been transferred for residence living or sleeping purposes by one 1 of the following methods i leased let or rented ii sold under the terms of a land contract which has not been recorded with the chippewa county register of deeds residential rental property does not include a rooming houses  b multiple dwellings of class b  c bed and breakfast houses  d reserved e a multiple dwelling of class a or class c used for students attending a state licensed or state chartered college or university when the property is owned by the college or university f a dwelling operated or licensed by the state or the federal government  122198   41519 required owners shall separately register each residential rental property a registry of owners agents and residential rental property shall be maintained by the footnotes  5  cross reference noise in hawking goods constituting a nuisance  1874 division 1  generally definitions the word peddler as used in this article shall include any person whether a resident of the city or not traveling by foot wagon automotive vehicle or any other type of conveyance from place to place from house to house or from street to street carrying conveying or transporting goods wares merchandise meats fish vegetables fruits garden truck farm products or provisions offering and exposing the same for sale or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers  or who without traveling from place to place shall sell or offer the same for sale from a wagon automotive vehicle railroad car or other vehicle or conveyance  or who solicits orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers the word peddler shall include the word hawker or huckster 01 duty of police to enforce it shall be the duty of any police officer of the city to require any person seen peddling and who is not known by such officer to be duly licensed to produce a peddlers license and to enforce the provisions of this section against any person found to be violating the same 10 cross reference police ch 19 use of streets peddlers shall not have any exclusive right to any location in the public streets nor shall they be permitted a stationary location nor shall they be permitted to operate in any congested area where their operations might impede or inconvenience the public for the purpose of this article the judgment of a police officer exercised in good faith shall be deemed conclusive as to whether the area is congested or the public impeded or inconvenienced 08 cross reference streets sidewalks and other public places ch 22 records of 1011717084 state law reference state fire prevention act mcl  291 et seq msa  1 et seq article i  in general mission statement the city fire department has been established to protect the citizens and property of the city and the county from fire and other threatening circumstances our commitment is to provide a professional service of the highest quality to all in need to meet this commitment the city fire department will provide its citizens with a timely response to any emergency situation with highest trained personnel available our goal is not only to help those in need but to remove the threat to the community all together fire prevention programs progressive training and years of experience our primary responsibility is to provide a safe and peaceful community where our citizens can work and raise a family  secs 1221215  reserved article ii  fire department footnotes  2  cross reference administration ch 2  fire chiefs approval required for transitory shows and exhibitions  6106 fire chief a the fire department shall be headed by the fire chief who shall be charged with the prevention and extinguishment of fires the protection of life and property against fire and the removal of fire hazards b the fire chief shall be responsible for the maintenance and care of all property used by the fire department 01 divisions the fire department may be divided into one or more divisions which may include but shall not be restricted to the following 1 extinguishment division which shall be responsible for the extinguishment of fires the saving of life and miscellaneous public services of an emergency nature  2 fire prevention division supervised by a fire hazard inspector who shall be responsible for the inspecting of potential fire hazards the abatement of existing fire hazards and the conducting of an educational fire prevention program 02 auxiliary fire corps a an auxiliary fire corps hereinafter called corps is hereby established as a voluntary organization composed of persons appointed by the fire chief hereinafter called the chief b the chief shall have complete authority and control over the corps the chief may appoint as members thereof any person whom such chief deems to be qualified and may reject any application for membership the chief may provide for the training of candidates for membership and for further training of members membership in this organization shall be limited to men over the age of eighteen 18 c no person shall become a member of the corps until such person has taken the training and is able to meet all other requirements prescribed by the chief when so qualified and selected such person shall then be sworn in by the chief or the chiefs representative as a member of the corps d the duties of the corps subject at all times to the direction supervision and control of the chief shall be to assist the regular members of the fire department of this city in the prevention and extinguishment of fires the protection of life and property against fire and the removal of fire hazards whenever and whenever its services are required the chief may by order establish rules and regulations to govern the corps including the fixing of specific duties of its members and providing for the maintenance of discipline the chief may change such orders from time to time e identification card badge and cap and such other insignia or evidence of identification as the chief may prescribe shall be issued to each member who shall carry the card at all times each member shall surrender all city property issued to such member upon the termination of membership f the membership of any person in the corps may be terminated for cause by the chief at any time and such member may resign from the corps at any time upon notifying the chief in writing of such persons resignation  provided however that the personnel regulations of the city manager applicable to fulltime regular city employees shall not be applicable to the corps and the civil service laws of the state applicable to firemen shall not be applicable to any member of the corps g the chief may by order diminish or expand the membership of the corps as existing conditions may require subject to the approval of the city manager h it shall be a misdemeanor for any person not a member of the corps 1 to wear carry or display a corps identification card badge cap or insignia  or 2 in any manner to represent themselves to be connected with the corps i each member of the corps while acting under the direction of the chief shall be deemed an employee of the city and shall be entitled to receive workmens compensation from the city in accordance with the provisions of the workmens compensation law of the state if any member sustains an illness or injury covered by the workmens compensation law not caused by intoxication or willful misconduct and not intentionally selfinflicted which with or without negligence is approximately caused by and arises out of and in the course of the performance of such members duties while acting under the direction of the chief then irrespective of such members remuneration from other employment such members average weekly earnings shall be conclusively presumed to be the amount necessary to receive the maximum disability and death benefits provided at that time by the and regulations required no person shall violate any law of the state nor any rule or regulation adopted by any duly authorized agency of the state pertaining to gasoline service stations michigan storage and handling of flammable and combustible liquids rules and michigan underground storage tank rules 01   definitions a the term gasoline service station when used in this division shall mean any premises including all buildings and structures thereon devoted to selling or dispensing at retail or wholesale gasoline or volatile liquids as fuel for any motorpropelled vehicle watercraft aircraft or internalcombustion engine  or where oil oil changes or other lubricating service is offered to the public at wholesale or retail b the term gasoline or volatile liquids when used in this division shall mean any inflammable liquid that will flash or emit an inflammable vapor below the temperature of one hundred twenty 120 degrees fahrenheit the fire code official of the fire department shall determine the flash point by standard approved methods 02   license required a no person shall conduct operate or manage a gasoline service station without first obtaining a license therefor from the city clerk in the manner provided for in chapter 14 b no license required by this division shall be issued by the city clerk except upon certification by the fire code official of the fire department that such gasoline service station complies with the provisions of this division 03   cross reference licenses and permits ch 14 prohibited locations of service stations no gasoline service station shall hereafter be constructed or opened for business within a radius of forty 40 feet of any school building public park or playground church community building theater or any other place where the public frequently gather in large numbers  provided that this section shall not extend to any gasoline station operating or in the process of being constructed at the date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this section was derived 04   5504 7758   equipment permit when required the storing or keeping of gasoline or the installation erection alteration or replacement of any gasoline pump gasoline tank pipe appliance or device used in connection with the storage or handling of gasoline at a gasoline service station shall not be undertaken until a written permit has been issued therefor by the fire code official of the fire department this section shall not apply to general maintenance activities of wholesale stations nor to emergency repairs except that such work must be done in accordance with the provisions of this 05   installation of underground storage tanks a all underground gasoline tanks hereafter installed shall be placed outside of buildings in a location approved by the fire code official of the fire department the top of such tanks shall be at least twentyfour 24 inches below the surface of the ground with the space between the top of tanks and ground properly filled or shall be covered with one 1 foot of earth and six 6 inches of concrete b all pipes used in connection with underground storage tanks other than vent and filling pipes shall be at least twelve 12 inches underground shall have a fall toward the tank shall be free of sags or pockets and shall be standard full weight galvanized steel or iron or copper c tanks and pipes shall not be covered until inspected and tested by the fire code official of the fire department and permission to do so has been granted by the fire code official the fire code official of the fire department shall be notified when the installation is complete and ready for inspection the fire code official of the fire department shall not approve any installation until the same has been inspected by such fire code official and has been tested with air at a pressure of five 5 pounds per square inch above atmospheric pressure and has demonstrated its ability to hold air at such pressure without loss of pressure due to leakage for a period of one 1 hour d all underground tanks and piping shall be in accordance with the michigan underground storage tank rules 06   safety provisions a smoking is hereby prohibited on the premises of a gasoline service station the motor of an automobile shall not be in operation while the fuel tank is being filled with gasoline notice to that effect shall be conspicuously posted as required by the chief of the fire department b no fuel tank shall be filled at a retail gasoline service station except hose connected to a pump of a type approved by the underwriters laboratories incorporated c no gasoline or inflammable liquid shall be kept or conveyed in open receptacles or in glass bottles or other breakable containers on the premises of a gasoline service station except in glass bottles of not more than eight 8 ounces capacity used for sample purposes no gasoline shall be used for cleaning purposes on such premises no glass container gasoline pump shall be installed in any building d all combustible waste and rubbish including crankcase drainings shall be kept in metal receptacles fitted with a tight cover until removed from the gasoline service stations e no gasoline oil grease or inflammable liquid shall be allowed to flow into or be placed in the drainage system of gasoline service stations oil and grease shall not be allowed to accumulate on the floor of gasoline service stations sawdust shall not be kept in any gasoline service station or place of storage and sawdust or other combustible material shall not be used to absorb oil grease or gasoline f all gasoline service station proprietors and attendants upon being notified by the chief of the fire department of the presence of gasoline or volatile liquids in sewers shall cooperate in ascertaining the reason therefor any expense to the city in tracing gasoline leaks shall be paid by the owner of the station responsible for such gasoline division respecting the use operation maintenance and construction of any appliance device apparatus equipment or oil burner used in connection with gasoline or volatile liquids including fuel oil h alley 08 secs 12821287  reserved division 5  hazardous chemicals scope this division shall apply to materials not otherwise covered in this are highly flammable or which may react to cause fires or explosions or which by their presence create or augment a fire or explosion hazard or which because of their toxicity flammability or explosive character render fire fighting abnormally dangerous or difficult  also to flammable liquids which are chemically unstable and which may spontaneously form explosive compounds or undergo spontaneous reactions of explosive violence or evolve sufficient heat to be a fire hazard hazardous chemicals shall include but shall not be restricted to such materials as compressed gases flammable solids corrosive liquids radioactive materials oxidizing materials and poisonous gases 01 definitions the following words and phrases when used in this division shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them compressed gas shall mean and include any mixture or material having in its container either an absolute pressure exceeding forty 40 pounds per square inch at seventy 70 degrees fahrenheit or an absolute pressure exceeding one hundred and five 105 pounds per square inch at one hundred thirty 130 degrees fahrenheit or both  or any liquid flammable material having a reid vapor pressure exceeding forty 40 pounds per square inch at one hundred 100 degrees fahrenheit corrosive liquids shall mean and include those acids alkaline caustic liquids and other corrosive liquids which when in contact with living tissue will cause severe damage to such tissue by chemical action  or which are liable to cause fire when in contact with organic matter or with certain chemicals flammable solid shall mean and include a solid substance other than one classified as an explosive which is liable to cause fires of moisture chemical changes or as a result of retained heat during manufacturing or processing oxidizing materials shall mean and include substances such as chlorates permanganates peroxides or nitrates that yield oxygen readily to stimulate combustion poisonous gas shall mean and include any noxious gas of such nature that a small amount of the gas when mixed with air is dangerous to life examples are chlorpicrin cyanogen hydrogen cyanide nitrogen peroxide and phosgene radioactive material shall mean and include any material or combination of material that spontaneously emits ionizing radiation vapor pressure shall mean the pressure measured in pounds per square inch absolute exerted by a volatile liquid as determined by the standard method of test for vapor pressure of petroleum products reid method american society for testing materials designation astmd 323 02 permit required a permit from the city clerk shall be required for the storage use or handling of more than fiftyfive 55 gallons of corrosive liquid  or more than five hundred 500 pounds of oxidizing materials  or more than five hundred 500 millicuries of radioactive material  or more than two thousand 2000 cubic feet of flammable compressed gas  or any amount of poisonous gas 03 cross reference licenses and permits ch 14 general requirements a the storage handling and use of hazardous chemicals shall be safeguarded with such protective facilities as public safety requires b the chief of the fire department may require the separation or isolation of any chemical that in combination with other substances may bring about a fire or explosion or may liberate a flammable or poisonous gas the chief of the fire department may require separation from other storage occupancies or buildings when in the chiefs opinion the quantity stored constitutes a material hazard c defective containers which permit leakage or spillage shall be disposed of or repaired in accordance with recognized safe practices  no spilled materials shall be allowed to accumulate d where specific requirements are not otherwise established compliance with the recommendations contained in the table of common hazardous chemicals of the national fire protection association nfpa no 49 the safety data sheets of the manufacturing chemists association or the pamphlets g1 g2 g3 g4 p1 and p2 of the compressed gas association inc with respect to the particular chemicals shall be considered as prima facie evidence of compliance with this section 04 compressed gases a storage rooms for compressed gases shall be cool dry and well ventilated b cylinders shall be stored away from radiators and other sources of heat no part of any cylinder containing compressed gas shall be subjected to temperatures above one hundred twentyfive 125 degrees fahrenheit c where caps are provided for valve protection they shall be kept on all cylinders not connected to gas utilization equipment d cylinders shall not be used as rollers supports or for any purpose other than to store the gas for which they are designed cylinders shall not be handled with lifting magnets rope slings or chain slings  a crane may be used when a safe cradle or platform is provided to hold the cylinders e refilling of cylinders shall be done only in compliance with interstate commerce commission regulations f each cylinder shall carry a legible label or stencil identifying its contents 05 oxidizing materials oxidizing materials shall be stored in dry locations and separated from organic materials including wooden surfaces 06 radioactive materials a adequate signs warning of radiation dangers shall be placed at entrances to locations where radioactive materials are used or stored signs will not be required for storage of manufactured articles other than liquids such as instruments or clock dials of which radioactive materials are a component part and luminous compounds when securely packed in strong containers provided the gamma radiation at any surface of the package is less than ten 10 milliroentgens in twentyfour 24 hours b when not in use radioactive materials shall be kept in adequately shielded fireresistant containers of such design that the gamma radiation will not exceed two hundred 200 milliroentgens per hour or equivalent at any point of readily accessible surface 07 poisonous gases a storage of poisonous gases shall be in rooms of at least onehour fireresistant construction and having natural or mechanical ventilation adequate to remove leaking gas such ventilation shall not discharge to a point where the gases may endanger any person b adequate warning signs stating the nature of the hazard shall be placed at all entrances to locations where poisonous gases are stored or used 08 corrosive liquids satisfactory provisions shall be made for containing and neutralizing or safely flushing away leakage of corrosive liquids which may occur during storage handling or use 09 secs 129712200  reserved article iv  hazardous materials incident cost recovery purpose the city finds that a significant potential exists for fire department responses to incidents involving the release or threatened release of hazardous materials such incidents create a great likelihood of personal injury andor property damage the control and abatement of such incidents places a significant financial and operational burden upon the citys firefighting and rescue services  3606 definitions unless specifically defined below words or phrases used in this article shall be interpreted so as to give them the meaning they have in common usage and to give this article its most reasonable application building means any structure emergency response means the providing sending andor utilizing firefighting emergency medical and rescue services by the city or by a private entity or corporation operating at the request or direction of the city or state for an incident resulting in a hazardous material release or threatened release expenses of an emergency response means the direct and reasonable costs incurred by the city or a private person corporation or other assisting government agency which is operating at the request or direction of the city when making an emergency response to the hazardous materials incident including the costs of providing police firefighting rescue services emergency medical services containment and abatement of all hazardous conditions at the scene of the incident the costs further include all of the salaries and wages of city personnel responding to the incident salaries and wages of city personnel engaged in the investigation supervision and report preparation regarding said incident all salaries and wages of personnel assisting government agencies operating at the request or direction of the city and all costs connected with the administration of the incident relating to any prosecution of the persons responsible including those relating to the production and appearance of witnesses at any court proceedings in relation thereto costs shall also include such items as disposable materials and supplies used during the response to said incident the rental or leasing of equipment used for the specific response replacement of equipment which is contaminated beyond reuse or repair during the response to said incident special technical services and laboratory cost and services and supplies purchased for any specific evacuation relating to said incident hazardous material means explosives pyrotechnics flammable compressed gas flammable liquid combustible liquid oxidizing material poisonous gas poisonous liquid irritating material etiological material radioactive material corrosive materials or liquefied petroleum gas owner means any person having a vested or contingent interest in the building personal property premises container or vehicle involved in the hazardous materials incident premises means any lot or parcel of land and includes a parking lot tourist camp trailer camp airport stockyard junkyard wharf pier public roadway and any other place however owned used or occupied vehicle means any device which is used as an instrument of conveyance including but not limited to motor vehicles railroads boats or aircraft  3606 liability for expense of an emergency response persons responsible the owner lessee operator or occupant or of any building premises personal property or vehicle regarding which an incident arises which involves the release or threatened release or hazardous materials on or about said building premises personal property or vehicle shall be required to reimburse the city for all expenses of any emergency response to said hazardous materials incident this personal liability shall be joint and several among the various parties charge against person the expense of an emergency response shall be a charge against the persons responsible under this article the charge constitutes a debt of that person and is collectible by the city in the same manner as in the case of an obligation under contract express or implied cost recovery schedule the city shall by resolution adopt a schedule of the costs included within the expense of an emergency response billing the city may within ten 10 days of receiving itemized costs or any part thereof incurred for an emergency response submit a bill for these costs by first class mail or personal service to the persons responsible for the expenses as enumerated under this article the bills shall require full payment within thirty 30 days from the date of mailing or service of said bill upon the persons responsible failure to pay and procedure to recover costs any failure to pay said bill within the thirty 30 days of mailing or service of this bill shall constitute a default on said bill in case of default the city shall have the right and power to add all emergency response costs to the tax roll as to any such property involved in the hazardous materials incident the city shall follow section 109 of the charter and chapter 21 of the the making of such assessment the city shall also have the concurrent right to bring action in a court of competent jurisdiction to collect said costs against the persons responsible if the city deems such action to be necessary  3606 conflicting ordinances repealed any and all other ordinances inconsistent with the provisions of the article and any changes adopted thereto are to the extent of such inconsistency hereby repealed  3606 severability if any section subsection clause paragraph or provision of this article shall be adjudged invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction such adjudication shall only apply to the said portion thereof adjudicated invalid and the full remaining portions of parts of this article shall remain in full force and effect  3606 savings clause all proceedings pending and all rights and liabilities existing acquired or incurred at the time this article takes effect are hereby saved and such proceedings may be consummated under and according or proceeding hereafter instituted under any ordinance specifically or impliedly repealed by this article and any changes thereto for any liabilities incurred or offenses committed before the effective date of this article and all proceedings pending at the effective date of this article and all proceedings or prosecutions instituted after the effective date of this article for any liabilities incurred or offenses committed before the effective date of this article may be continued or instituted under and in accordance with the provisions of any ordinance in force at the time of materials is an important public purpose b the separation and collection of paper cardboard glass cans and vegetative yard waste for recycling from the residential commercial and institutional establishments in this municipality will minimize the adverse environmental effects of landfilling by reducing the need for landfills and conserving existing landfill capacity facilitate the to nonsupport and was derived from original   unlawful discrimination in housing andor real property a declaration of policy 1 in furthering the policy of the state as expressed in its constitution and other laws  in order that the safety and general welfare peace and health of all the inhabitants of the city may be ensured it is hereby declared the policy of the city to assure equal opportunity to all residents regardless of race color religion national origin or ancestry sex creed or physical disability to live in decent sanitary healthful standard living quarters 2 it is the policy of the city that no owner lessee sublessee assignee managing agent or other person firm or corporation having the right to sell rent lease or otherwise control any housing accommodation andor real property within the city or any agent of these shall refuse to sell rent lease or otherwise deny to or withhold from any person or group of persons such housing accommodations andor real property because of race color religion national origin or ancestry sex creed or disability of such person or persons or discriminate against any person or persons because of race color religion national origin or ancestry sex creed or disability in the conditions terms privileges of the sale rental or lease of any housing accommodation andor real property or in the furnishing of facilities andor services in connection therewith 3 relocation shall be carried out in a manner that will promote maximum choice within the communitys total housing supply  lessen racial ethnic and economic concentrations  and facilitate desegregation and racially inclusive patterns of occupancy and use of public and private facilities b definitions unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context the following terms shall have the meaning as described in this subsection and as used in this section decent sanitary healthful standard living quarters means housing which is in sound clean and weather tight condition in conformance with applicable local state and national codes discriminate or discrimination mean any difference expressed in any way toward a person or persons in the terms of the sale exchange lease rental or financing for housing accommodation andor real property in regard to such sale exchange rental lease or finance because of race color religion national origin or ancestry sex creed or disability of such person housing accommodation includes any building structure or portion thereof which is used or occupied maintained arranged or designed to be used or occupied as a home considered to be public nuisances per se app a  101252501 definition for the purposes of this chapter the word nuisance is hereby defined as anything prohibited by this chapter or as any person doing an unlawful act or omitting to perform a duty or suffering or permitting any condition or thing to be or exist which act omission condition or thing either 1 injures or endangers the comfort repose health or safety of others  or 2 offends decency  or 3 is offensive to the senses  or 4 unlawfully interferes with obstructs or tends to obstruct or renders dangerous for passage any public or private street highway sidewalk stream ditch or drainage  or 5 in any way renders other persons insecure in life or the use of property  or 6 essentially interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of life and property or tends to depreciate the value of the property of others prohibited it shall be unlawful for any person to cause permit maintain or allow the creation or maintenance of a nuisance 02 enforcement a the city manager may elect to enforce the provisions of this chapter by one of the following methods or by any combination thereof 1 prosecute the person committing creating or maintaining the nuisance for a violation of the provisions of this   or 2 cause the nuisance to be immediately abated under section 1812  or 3 give notice in the manner provided in section 188 ordering such nuisance to be abated b whenever any nuisance endangers the health of the public the health officer shall have the power to enforce this chapter in the same manner as such power is maintaining the nuisance contents of notice the notice to abate a nuisance issued under the provisions of this chapter shall contain 1 an order to abate the nuisance or to request a hearing within a stated time which shall be reasonable under the circumstances  2 the location of the nuisance if the same is stationary  3 a description of what constitutes the nuisance  4 a statement of acts necessary to abate the nuisance  5 a statement that if the nuisance is not abated as directed and no request for hearing is made within the prescribed time the city will abate such nuisance and assess the cost thereof against such person service of notice the notice to abate a nuisance shall be served as any other legal process may be served pursuant to law abatement by city upon the failure of the person upon whom notice to abate a nuisance was served pursuant to the provisions of this chapter to abate the same the city manager or other duly designated officer of the city shall proceed to abate such nuisance and shall prepare a statement of costs incurred in the abatement thereof emergency abatement by city when in the opinion of the city manager or other duly designated officer there is actual and immediate danger to the public or occupants of a particular premises caused by a nuisance on such premises the city manager or duly designated officer is hereby authorized and empowered without any notice or hearing to order and require such premises to be vacated the city manager or other duly designated officer shall immediately post the premises warning of the dangerous condition and shall then abate such nuisance and prepare a statement of costs incurred in the abatement thereof collection of citys costs of abatement any and all costs incurred by the city in the abatement of a nuisance under the provisions of this chapter shall be collected from the owner or occupant of the property upon which the nuisance was committed created or maintained in an action at law or they may be charged against the premises as a special assessment in accordance with the provisions of article v of chapter 21 03 motor vehicle sound an owner operator person in charge of in possession
